Your device supports Project Treble.

Version
VNDK Lite
Legacy
This is the version of the Vendor Native Development Kit used to build your device\'s vendor partition. It represents the lowest Android version that can be installed on the system partition.
VNDK Lite disables some isolation between the system and vendor partitions at runtime, resulting in a smaller but less versatile vendor partition.
On vendors built with Android 8.1 or lower, a legacy path is used for the device manifest.
Project Treble allows supported Android devices to boot a Generic System Image, reducing the time required for updates to be developed.
This is the name of the Generic System Image required by your device. Names may vary slightly. Click here to browse some Generic System Images created by the community.

The system partition can be mounted either as the root filesystem (System-as-Root) or in a subdirectory of the root ramdisk (System-as-System). Many GSIs incorrectly refer to this property as A/B. If a device uses System-as-Root, it requires an A/B GSI. Otherwise, it requires an A-only GSI.

Although many GSIs refer to A/B images, this value is not directly linked to the GSI image type. Devices with A/B partitions are able to store two copies of Android at once. This allows updating one copy while the other is in use.

Devices with Dynamic Partitions are able to create, modify or delete partitions during updates. To support this feature, a \"super\" partition is used. This container partition contains all other partitions except for the bootloader. Flashing must be performed using fastbootd on these devices.
Unable to detect Virtual A/B support.
Your device does not use Virtual A/B partitioning.
Your device uses Virtual A/B partitioning.
Unable to detect Virtual A/B retrofit status.
Your device does not use retrofitted Virtual A/B partitions.
Your device uses retrofitted Virtual A/B partitions.
Unable to detect Virtual A/B compression status.
Your device does not use compressed Virtual A/B partitioning.
Your device uses compressed Virtual A/B partitioning.
Virtual A/B
Virtual A/B allows a device to perform Seamless Upgrades without needing to permanently keep two copies of Android.
Virtual A/B Retrofit
Devices with retrofitted Virtual A/B have empty space in the super partition.
Virtual A/B Compression
On devices that use Virtual A/B, the changes made can be compressed. This reduces performance but decreases storage requirements during the update.

The architecture of the CPU determines which programs can be run on the device, and must match the operating system. The binder architecture controls how programs communicate. Since the vendor partition programs need to communicate with the system partition programs, the binder architecture must match between the two.
